page.title: 01The development of Rochdale.
page.content: Rochdale is sited in the valley of the River Roch, a tributary of the River Irwell, which is also part of the River Mersey basin. The original point of settlement was a ford where the River Roch could be crossed and later a bridge was built to replace the ford. Around the bridge grew a small market centre which served the needs of the surrounding area. Slowly the village became a town and today much of the town centre is built on a very large bridge. Rochdale is surrounded by moorlands. To the East are the Pennines and to the North are the Rossendale Uplands. The hills consist of millstone grit, a very coarse sandstone.
